SENT.plain: In January, 1995, a 64-year-old man became dizzy and vomited for several hours
48 h later he was drowsy, confused, and dysphasic
His pulse was 80/min and regular; blood pressure 220/110 mm Hg
He had small equal pupils, no nystagmus or neck stiffness, diminished power in the right arm and leg with increased tone, and some right ankle clonus
His previous medical history was unremarkable
Urea (8·7 mmol/L), glucose (8·2 mmol/L), and creatine kinase (853 U/L) were elevated
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 22 mm/h
A computed tomography (CT) brain scan on admission (figure) was interpreted as showing a primary intracerebral haemorrhage in the left temporoparietal region
Neurosurgeons and neuroradiologists thought the scan showed haemorrhagic transformation of a large arterial infarct in the middle cerebral artery territory
Necropsy showed cardiomegaly, symmetrical left-ventricular hypertrophy, and a fenestrated patent foramen ovale
Histologically verified ante-mortem thrombus was present in right and left atria, adding to the clinical interpretation that the brain lesion had resulted from an arterial embolus
